review_title: It's always some good and some bad
pros: Great pay 70k-150k in most areas. You can make 100k+ in your first year. The benefits are extremely good. Some of the older guys complain because they use to not have to pay anything but for about $230 you and your entire family are covered. Oh yeah this is the easiest work you probably will ever do however the hours are long.
cons:
Furloughs and culture change. In these days and times you are guaranteed to get laid off at some point in your early career but they will definitely call back. Also, they change rules, management and the way of life so much you never get use to anything. the work schedule being on call is also tough for most people. They have many ways to take off but they are minimizing those by the day and their point system is rough.
Advice to Management
Management has actually improved over the last few years. It's some changes that need to be made but they are mostly within the agreement so with time it may get better.

pros: I honestly don't have any reason to work for this dishonest corporate nightmare.
cons:
-Lies. Nothing they say or promise is ever the truth.
-Abuse. I have never seen any company treat their workers with more contempt.
-Loyalty. They expect 110%, yet give none in return.
-Training. They have all but given up on all but the most strictly enforced, federally mandated training. Zero support.
-Safety. Goes out the window as soon as managers want something that will benefit them. UP DOES NOT CARE ABOUT SAFETY. And God forbid you get hurt, they will hang you any way they can.
-Family. Don't count on having one if you choose to work here.

pros: High salary, great health coverage.
cons:
Shift work, short call time, on-call schedule, management ignoring agreements for the company's benefit. Low employee morale for all except those in corporate.
Advice to Management
While I was at UP, morale was at an all-time low. Constant disputes over the UTU agreement, management ignoring or flat out violating union agreements for the benefit of the company(and possibly their personal bonuses.) Shift work should be on a rotating schedule like the medical industry, or the industrial industry, or really ANY other industry that has an on-call shift work schedule. No other industry has a 24/7/365 on-call schedule without also having designated off days for its employees.

pros: Work was a true 8 hours. Work was online real time transactions. No conference calls. Ample training. Real life resources and subject matter experts to consult. It was the one place I worked in which no one ever made me feel bad for asking a question even if I should have already known the answer from experience. Railroad retirement rather then social security.
cons:
Corporate Culture. Every level from the yard, to the trainmen, to maintenance, to the dispatchers were not provided adequate tools or staffing to do their job. Hence, every call is a problem. The people that get promoted and retained is unexplainable. Even with a six figure salary, 401(K) match, railroad retirement etc I hated having to go to work their each day. Very little career mobility. These folks fired people and sold off assets (selma farms) to get to their operating ratio.

This should be a dream job. Making over a billion dollars per quarter and constantly being in the Forbes top listings there is no excuse for such a corporate culture.

pros: The pay and benefits are good for now.

review_title: Look elsewhere, especially if you're not a white male
pros: If you are one of the chosen ones you will have some opportunities until you fall out of favor
cons:
Very toxic environment for both management and agreement employees. There is no job stability with this company. Employees live in constant fear of being laid off/let go with no warning. Cuts are made by executive leadership without input from direct supervisors or teams. 
The company is paying lip service to wanting to hire more females and diverse candidates, but puts no effort into developing or promoting the current female and diverse employees.
Promotional/Growth opportunities are extremely limited. Upper level management is shuffled from department to department, and they bring their favorites with them. It's unfortunate that employees with departmental experience aren't even able to apply for promotional opportunities because an executive will make the "business decision" to bring someone with no experience over from a different department without even posting the position. Working your way up doesn't exist here, you must get in good with an executive in order to promote.
Advice to Management
You're going down a terrible path and using the words "business decision" to justify your actions. Stop making excuses and take responsibility for your decisions. Talk to your employees one on one and get to know them. If there is a concern, call that employee directly and communicate with them more than once a year. Stop communicating solely via metrics and data, numbers aren't more important than people. Before you say or do something, ask yourself if you would want someone to treat one of your kids the way you are about to treat an employee. You are really hurting the people who work for you and don't seem to care at all. People deserve better, regardless of whether they are management or union employees.
Helpful (13

review_title: You are just a warm body in a seat
pros:
paycheck has never bounced

you can always quit...i think...honestly not sure about that though. They might actually fire you for trying to quit.
cons:
So many to name, 
 - There is absolutely no managerial accountability for anything. (It's out of their hands, they know nothing about it, it's impossible to fix, it's been that way for 20 years, I'll get back to you, or more often than not...well, it's your fault)

 - a new attendance policy has been implemented in which an employee could work for 362 days (being available for call, on duty, or resting) and need to take a Friday, Saturday, and Sunday off - and they will be jobless upon their return.

On call 24/7/365 with no set days off

 - are denied earned compensated leave days due to "manpower shortage" as the company constantly manipulates staffing to ensure it always has the absolute minimum amount of people available to operate

 - constantly and consistently violates the Collective Bargaining Agreement, which is the contract we work under, forcing employees to work out of proper rest, off of qualified areas, and doing jobs designated to other groups and threaten termination

 - employment termination is constantly threatened by the terms "Failure to Comply" and "Insubordination" being used at every opportunity to justify a company officer's abuse of power and disregard for employees' safety, rest, quality of life, morale, and overall well being.

 - Never being able to plan anything longer than 2 hours in advance...ever

 - not being able to participate or engage in normal life without constantly checking to see if you are going to get called for work, but even then, due to the complete lack of regard by management, even if you think you can mow your lawn for an hour without checking your phone, chances are they will call you to work and if you don't answer within 30 minutes of their first attempt...you are more than half way to being fired

on average, the normal railroader is awake for 24+ hours at a time. It is normal to be awake for 10-16 hours and then unexpectedly get called for work, in which days can range from 6 to 20 hours on duty. 

You never know when you will be going to work, what kind of job you will be working, how long you will be at work, or if by the time you drive to work that they wont send you home because they made a mistake, just so you can pull in your driveway to have them call you back to work.

There is no direct access to the payroll department

the people that you need to speak with to take time off (should you dare) either don't answer the phone (so you get to spend an hour on hold) or they are typically unpleasant condescending...leading to the next point

Nearly Every part of the management team at the local and regional level are conniving and condescending. 

The union representation is an absolute joke in which yo pay an absurd amount of monthly dues to a local in which your ONLY course of action in the case of an agreement violation is to file a claim - which is then immediately auto - denied by the payroll department, to which you submit a dispute to your union, in which you may see 10% of your claim value in 7 to 10 years...but that depends on if you are buddy buddy with a union official. if not...well sorry about your luck

The overall atmosphere at the railroad is similar to high school. Most of your co workers will spread gossip and misinformation based on what they heard someone else say they heard from a guy who was talking to someone that heard about a situation that somebody else heard about.

most people are more concerned with what everyone else is doing than minding their own business, and someone always has something to say about how they think you aren't doing what they think you should be doing.


The only thing Union Pacific truly cares about is that you are available to answer the phone and show up to work your train. Not Health, not safety, not its employees, not veterans, not family. All of that is marketing and for the shareholders.
Advice to Management
Get a clue and try to remember what it was like to be a decent human being that actually cared for his fellow man rather than constantly worrying about how you are going to hide or misrepresent the numbers that truly reflect how ineffective and inefficient you are at your job
Helpful (2
advice_to_mgmt: Get a clue and try to remember what it was like to be a decent human being that actually cared for his fellow man rather than constantly worrying about how you are going to hide or misrepresent the numbers that truly reflect how ineffective and inefficient you are at your job

pros: RRB retirement is higher than social security, but this “pro” assumes you’ll work there long enough to retire, which is rare under the current business model.
cons:
The company is always looking to cut headcount; your job is never safe. The cuts are so drastic that the workforce is very limited and works with limited resources. This is a very challenging culture - you get advanced if you’re in the “circle,” but if you’re not, getting recognized and promoted is rare. The company says they value diversity and equity, but their actions don’t support that proposition. I would never recommend this company to any prospective employee. The benefits for new employees aren’t enough to overcome the poor pay and terrible culture.
Advice to Management
Start making a change to leadership - once your board, top executives, and department leaders reflect diversity, you can say that the company does. You are no longer a premier employer, other companies are running circles around you with pay and benefits. The company culture is terrible and sending engagement surveys isn’t fixing it.

review_title: Not a career for a person who is family oriented person
pros: Great career if you are single or have no kids. Jobs pay great!
cons:
No life! Management is constantly changing job rest days and schedule so that you are having to exercise seniority on to different shifts which causes a large disturbance. You will be on graveyard one week to swing the next, and morning shift is for those who have been there forever but the bottom guys are on the cusp of shift changes. The phrase, "Watch the bump" will be rumbled for days. You will rarely ever get any weekends off unless you have 20 years plus, and no general sicks days with a strict attendance policy. No promotions within the company unless you are changing crafts. Ex: apprenticeships when they are offered every 3-5 years, but they hire outsiders for management.
Advice to Management
Be more considerate with time off as family values need to be incorporated. Working for a company for 30 years and always having to worry if you will be bumped is not a healthy way to live.

review_title: Complete disregard for employee work/family balance.
pros: Decent Heath Insurance and Retirement.
cons:
Constant change, causes constant worry. Will I have to move my family without any relocation package, will I get laid off? 
Personal Experience: I'm a 7 year employee moving closing to my headquartered location, five days before new home closing date ..... UP abolished jobs, no warning or heads up. Forced to back out of house. To retain job, moved family out of state 9hrs away from previous home and all family. Worked 1.5 yrs out of state, land job back home. Close on new house, move family 9hrs back home, three days after paying first house payment, UP abolished more jobs. Currently, I'm living separately from family, 6hrs from home, actively seeking employment and still worried... will I get laid off. I would not recommend Union Pacific to friends or enemies!
Advice to Management
Talk to each other. Plan ahead. Consider our families. Consider the children bouncing from school to school because their family invested in a career with Union Pacific.

review_title: PSR is a numbers game to keep shareholders (ONLY) happy
cons:
ltant in Omaha, NE
Doesn't Recommend
Negative Outlook
Disapproves of CEO
I have been working at Union Pacific full-time
Pros
*Salary is competitive
*Flexible for vacation/time off
*Able to work from home one day/week extended to every day through Covid
Cons
*Embrace of PSR has left employees, customers, and communities to suffer
*Eliminated pension for new employees after 2018
*Difficult to advance during PSR/Unified Plan 2020 as departments consolidate. I applied for 3 jobs in the past 2 years and they were all cancelled/combined with other jobs.
*Closed entire 40 person department with one-day notice. Severance packages were decent, but it would have been nice to give their employees more of a heads-up.
Advice to Management
Everything is so focused on the 55% operating ratio that successful service offerings are eliminated if they "cost too much." Company would rather see the business go away than work for it. Weak service means that shippers are not using rail and fewer trains/crews are needed, which means lower costs! They don't care about future prospects for customers/earnings when they can just reduce the operating ratio and get short-term gains. Unified Plan 2020 is going to need some serious unraveling after they hit the 55% operating ratio, if they can even make it. Once bulk commodities coal and frac sand are totally gone, they're going to need to scramble to find new customers-- the same ones they chased away in an effort to reduce costs!

pros: Pay and benefits are descent. Good retirement plan if you can last.
cons:
Forfeit of your quality of life. Very unstable job from about first to 15 years of seniority. Be prepared to be forced over 300 miles from your home terminal! Be prepared to be furloughed for months at a time. My first 17 years was ruff.1st day I marked up forced to work in a different location 120 miles from where I hired out. Had to sleep in my car many times because leasing a apartment was out of the question , you never knew when you would be forced to a different location. I had 6 years of seniority and was furloughed for 3 years Oct. 1985 until Oct. 1988. I have missed holidays, weddings, funerals and graduations. On call 24/7 may work at 100am one day and 200pm next day. You will never have a set sleep pattern. You will need to buy job insurance to protect your income if you get disciplined. You could be suspended for rules violations any where from 1 day up to 2 years without pay. That’s if the arbitrator puts you back to work. Or it could be termination. And believe me the railroad management test for rules violations all the time. They will watch you for hours until you make a mistake. They do random drug and alcohol test all the time. Then they have probable cause drug test any time something goes wrong or you violate a major rule they will drug test you.
Advice to Management
Do away with new absenteeism policy. It’s very anti productive.

pros:
I've spent my entire career at Union Pacific and while we have weathered various economic cycles throughout that time, I am still convinced this is one of the best companies in America. I attended a top 5 business school and had great opportunity to move to a different job but no other company could offer what I had at Union Pacific. The benefits are world class. Compensation has been competitive from the time I started as an entry level employee up to today. I am impressed with the degree of investment in training and developmental UP dedicates for their workforce. 

Many have criticized the senior leaders of the company but my perspective having worked at all levels of this organization is those criticizing lack an understanding of the market fundamentals that are forcing the company to change. While many prefer a status quo model, that is a going out of business strategy and our longevity for the past 150+ years is because we have learned to adapt to the different market swings. I love the people I work with every day. Railroaders are passionate about solving problems, building america, connecting businesses and the economy. I love going to work every day as our business provides significant value to communities, customer, employees, and investors that rely on our services. I love that we touch nearly every industry, from the food on your table, walls of your house, to the cars that you drive, to the buildings that you work in....we transport all of it. Without us, roads would be more congested than they are already. Businesses would close their doors as transportation costs made it impossible to compete. I'm proud to be a railroader of the Union Pacific.
cons:
Recent changes in our business have forced the company to reduce the number of jobs which is hard for all of us but I am confident we will grow again as the economy changes and as we adapt to the evolving market conditions.
Helpful (1

review_title: Hopefully moving in the right direction...
pros: Compensation, retirement package, HSA seed money, improved vacation, improved maternity/paternity leave, flextime, jeans, work from home
cons:
UP is filled some great, hard working peple, but there are still those few who need to step back, look themselves in the mirror, humble themselves, and treat others how they want to be treated. Think about the negative language, gossip, and body language you protrude onto others. And then think, would you want someone doing that to you and treating you that way? Honestly though, think about that question for one minute and if you answer "No I wouldn't want to be treated that way", then you have an opportunity to make a positive change in how you treat others.

We are all human beings. No one person is better than another. Period. There is nothing wrong with confidence, but you could start to create unwelcomed friction if abrasive arrogance takes over. Life's not about title or always being right. You can't take that with you on the other side. It's about what you did for others while you were here and how you treated them. 
Advice to Management
UP is at a turning point. They need to gain more market share and revive the culture, and fast. Both of those issues go hand-in-hand and are equally important. I wonder if employee retention and sales would improve if employees were placed #1 on the list vs shareholders and Wall Street.

Imagine getting written up by a manager who doesnt even know or understand the rule that he/she is writing you up for. Imagine not being able to call in sick(layoff) for an appointment in fear of being in violation of the attendance policy. Imagine working 6 days in a row, and getting penalized for coming to work by losing your guarantee(salary) for the pay period. Yes you are reading correctly, if you work 6 days in a row, you forfeit your guarantee(salary), and if you call in sick in an attempt to avoid that situation, you could possibly be in violation of the attendance policy. Imagine being handcuffed to your phone and trying to enjoy an evening with your family and each time, your job calls and says “we need you to come in and work in this place that you have never worked before and hurry up and finish all the work” I could go on and on but I am off write now and would like to spend time with my family before my phone rings. I guess i could request a vacation day, but they only approve those on Tuesdays and Wednesdays. Man I just love being off on those days(sarcasm). If you’re just dead set on becoming a railroader, I strongly suggest you try BNSF first. Its the lesser of the two evils, I guarantee it

pros:
Some of the people you work with are awesome, and others make you wonder if they have visiting hours where they live.

Paychecks always clear, though you never get paid what you should be by agreement.

I was happily able to leave on my own terms, so there's that!
cons:
You are quiet literally just a number in a system, and a warm body to fill a slot. You will be treated as an easily replaceable commodity, so be aware! You WILL be on call 24/7/365, and woe unto you if you anger the people in charge of the attendance policy in Omaha, even with their arbitrary enforcement of their made-on-the-fly rules. Have a spouse and/or kids? Hope you don't really like them as much as you say, because you'll never see them and watch them grow up. You're going to miss out on a lot of important events in their lives, because "Uncle Pete" now controls yours. Hope you like nasty Chinese food in a seedy hotel on Christmas! 

All that is if you are actually able to work and not be furloughed every year since your hire date, and currently people with 8-9 years seniority are on the bubble.

Like other reviews, this company will only hire you for a tax break, and will take every single chance it can get to fire you. It's the only job I've ever heard of where you have to get "fire insurance" in case you temporarily lose you job, or worse! 

The safety culture has really gone downhill since I hired on. At the very least, it was a facade of "Safety First" back then. But with the recent and on going changes safety is now blatantly in third place, behind the shareholders and profits respectively. review_title: UP needs to improve their culture if they want to succeed
pros: Great Pay (and I suppose opportunity to move up seeing as a lot of people are leaving/getting laid off/"involuntarily separated)
cons:
I was excited when I first joined up. Great OMT Program that psuedo-prepares you for management. Class said that if you were to have challenges, it would most likely be with the "Agreement Professionals" aka the union guys, but I guess I got lucky. All of my guys were amazing, and taught me more than management ever did (besides how to record/brief metrics). It's blatantly obvious that upper management really doesn't care about it's employees; I mean, read the other reviews. The company preaches work-life balance, but if you want to stand out and be good at your job (or perceived to be) you have to pull long hours, especially at when you're not at a big terminal and it's just you out there.
Since I left there have been 2 (maybe 3?) rounds of layoffs. All to maximize shareholder value. It's such a shame because they preach safety, but then reduce the amount of the workforce, Agree and Salary (like management) alike and expect safer, more efficient work ethic. I just don't see that happening... Overall, I learned a lot from UP in the short time I was there ( only 16 months), but I'm glad that I left. Think twice before applying, especially if you have a family.
Advice to Management
Please. Please think more about your employees. Read these reviews and take them seriously. I know it's a lot of gripes and complains, but they're for a reason. And no, it's not just because everyone except a few can't "adapt to change." 

If you walk into a room and you can point out an jerk, that guy is probably a jerk. But if you walk into a room and everyone is a jerk? You're the jerk.

pros: Its probably the best pay you can get without any training or a degree. You dont pay into social security anymore. You get railroad retirement (which is better than social security), a really good benefits package, and the option for a 401k after your first year of service.
cons:
Here we go...…

This job is ALL about seniority and without it, you are nothing! This means that even though you are the best worker with the best attendance you will still lose your job to a lazy jackwad with more seniority than you. This means that nobody has an incentive to go out and do a great job because it doesn't matter.

When you are a lower seniority employee you will most likely only be able to hold the jobs that nobody else wants. This will most likely mean you're on an "extraboard". Your work/life balance will be heavily one-sided towards work. You WILL miss all the holidays, birthdays, anniversaries, parties, etc! Unless you are on Federal Rest (FR) or Undisturbed Rest (UR) you will be on-call and live every minute by your phone. There will be days that you sit at home all day thinking you're going to work, and you dont.....Then there will be times when it looks like you'll have the whole day off, then get called right when you get to the lake. It is extremely hard to get a good amount of actual rest before getting on a train. 

Furloughs are a real thing! Unless you have a minimum of 5 years of service dont even think about buying anything big, like a house, boat, or expensive truck. You can be balls-to-the-wall busy for 2 years straight then all of a sudden and without notice you're cut off. 

This company only has one goal, and thats to make the shareholders as much money as possible. Union Pacific breaks revenue records every quarter and always makes more money than the previous year but that will not stop them from cutting jobs and overtime wherever they can. The employees are the biggest liability and the less there are of you the less the liability. They dont care how many kids you have, how many car payments you have or about the mortgage you have to pay. If cutting hundreds of people will make the shareholders money then thats what they will do. 

Union Pacific will fight you on every pay claim you try and submit. Their first action is to always deny your claim, then hope you dont come back and fight it. They also dont adhere you union agreements. If you are a new conductor they will call you and have you work a job that is outside of what you're supposed to be doing, then threaten you with a refusal to work if you dont accept it. However, its a lot harder for them to get away with this with the seasoned guys that know the agreements. 

You will be away from home a lot! I spent my first 9 months in a different state then I applied in. This goes to my first point about seniority. If people with higher seniority are working where your "home" is and no jobs are available there then you have to find somewhere else to work. Your only hope is for the company to add jobs in your home area or you can pray that the people with higher seniority either retire or move somewhere else.
Advice to Management
I dont have anything negative to say about my local managers. They do the best they can with what the company gives them and they are fair (This is not the case everywhere). 

My advice to Omaha would be to start caring for your employees. Richard Branson said "Clients do not come first. Employees come first. If you take care of your employees, they will take care of the clients." This is a quote that I wholeheartedly agree with. How much money do you have to make before you are happy? What number do you have to reach in order for you to keep your people working and putting food on their tables? When you are all sitting in that board meeting, perhaps the topic should be how you're going to keep people working.....instead of how many you have to cut to keep your coffers full.
Helpful (11

It's truly sad to see all the TE&Y workers they've "promised" good paying jobs then furloughed right away never to call them back, after most of them with families left other career's. Most employees walk around with their heads down and don't tell anyone they work for Union Pacific because of their embarrassment. pros: The pay is good and despite the slow erosion of benefits they are still good.
cons:
The company attempts to implement various new safety, productivity, efficiency, and disciplinary standards with little to no success with too much frequency. Too many programs have been tried without addressing the root cause of issues faced by labor. Management turn over has gone from bad to worse with each successive change becoming a new nightmare. Utilizing employees creativity in finding solutions has completely stopped and innovation is stifled. Too many protections for problem employees (often with higher seniority) have led to significant losses of skilled trade knowledge. The company has drifted far from the days when family values extended into the workplace. Workplace harassment is swiftly brushed aside or ignored altogether. There are so many unaddressed complaints about bad processes, safety in the yard, contractor immunity, and government regulation violations it is innumerable. 
I fear for my health and safety by continuing to work for this company. The measure by which certain departments are deemed productive uses false and inapplicable points of productivity.
Advice to Management
Drug test. Hold your contractors accountable for yard safety. Work to actually keep talented younger employees instead of keeping the lazy, and selfish "workers". 
Consider profit sharing for certain departments to instill pride in one's work quality and performance. Stop putting recent college graduates with no practical experience into management roles. Value the younger more physically able and mentally sharp employees instead of laying them off; you can begin to achieve that by allowing for earlier retirement once a minimum years of service is reached. Don't stifle creativity; we know the job and the tools best so pay attention to organic innovation. You can't increase shareholder value by laying off shareholders (employees). Reevaluate how you measure productivity by actually understanding the numerous variables you've conveniently forgotten.

review_title: I'm happy to be an Ex-employee
pros: Not many really, it used to be a great company to work for, a company with very little turnover. That is not the case anymore. The only positive thing that I can think of is the retirement pension, but even as I write this I am sure that there is a team in Omaha working on a way to eliminate this.
cons:
If you do not give at least 16 hours a day to this company you will never excel. The company has eliminated all of the support staff that we used to have in the past; Yardmasters, Clerks, Customer Service Reps etc.. The Transportation dept field manager does it all. Managers used to feel as if they were actually part of the company, now many feel as if they are unwanted guests on the property. I can only write this review based on my experiences and the feedback that I have received from my peers.

Your service unit Directors come in two classes of people: those who only talk about retirement, and those who are just nasty people. I cannot believe some of the conference calls that I was on at 6am. Service unit directors humiliating and belittling employees in front of the entire division. What a great way to start the day! pros: Wages...when they pay you correctly
cons:
They cut pay and in order to get it right they will hold the funds for years and years without any type of recourse other than letting your union officers handle it. Your union officers are paid bribes by the railroad or carrier, so in many cases you can kiss that little extra pay goodbye. Holiday pay? Nope. Overtime? Nope, they’ll pay a separate and apart transport time instead (screws you out of money). Auto miles? Yeah, they’ll try to say it takes 40 auto miles to go 90 miles the way the crow the flies...again...cutting your pay. 

On top of all of this, you accrue no sick time. The only leave is vacation (in the yard) and they’ll keep you 12 hours or more with no schedules to go by. You may be lined up for 8am and called at midnight. Then god forbid you’re tired and miss something...you’ll be fired...again...because the national labor board finds in favor of the employee more often than the railroad because they’ve broken some rule or agreement...it’s just pitiful.
Advice to Management
Whatever you think is working isn’t. If you’re thinking go right, let me be as blunt as I can and tell you you’re wrong...go left.

review_title: Too unstable and Company Does not Value Workers
pros: The Union protections are better than most places. The benefits are good plans, although the company does not actively tell you about them. You have to know what you are entitled to from the other employees and the Union. The company tries not to pay claims for insurance, and you must stay on top of them. But the plans themselves are good, especially for families.
cons:
The instability- constant layoffs are hard for family budget. In addition, the schedule of being constantly available is more stress than the money is worth. This instability will only be aggravated in the future because of the regulatory environment allowing one person crews once the Union contracts allow for it. There is also growing technology that will reduce the need for human workforce. UP puts employees and their families through extreme stress, with little to no appreciation or stability in order to improve their bottom line, which is constantly growing. I am looking for other employment.
Advice to Management
Guarantee income (besides Railroad Unemployment) during short times that require layoffs. Offer more scheduled departure times so that families can plan better. Appreciate employees instead of treating them badly until you can no longer need them- that is what it feels like to employees.

You will work 65-85 hours per week. Sometimes you will work 11 days in a row . You will work day and night. They will demote you even if your doing a great job to save money. All the employees are disgruntled and the culture is extremely negative. No one is happy there. They just feel trapped because of the pay.

review_title: We Have Lost too Many Good Employees; Culture is Ruined
pros:
1) Healthy pay for field managers. Salary + stock/bonus for high performers. I was marked in 2018 as a high performer and was paid very nicely for my time sacrifice. 
2) Promotional opportunity ever 1-3 years
cons:
Cons of Working in Field Operations:

1) Poor work life balance. Field managers work 90+ hours on road territories and are on call 24 hours of each work day. Terminal managers work 55-70 hours per week however they are fighting fires every minute of it. Its not just the hours that create the poor work life balance, it’s the stress. When you get home you are so on edge about your operation you can’t unwind. 
2) Culture: this is the biggest con by far. The company expects you as a manager to be a authoritarian dictator. I have a collaborative leadership style which is quite opposite of the authoritarian. I tried to lead my way and eventually you have no choice but to play their game and lead their way... otherwise the other managers who do lead their way will shine well above you and you will earn a target on your back. Their style over the years has instilled a negative mindset into every agreement professional’s head and had burned out a lot of good managers. 
3) Cost Cutting: Union Pacific is implementing precision schedule railroading which is effectively a major cost cutting effort. I believe PSR is good in a lot of respects. Everyone knows there is opportunity for our company to be more efficient with its money. Unfortunately we have cut too deep in key resources such as locomotives. I have trains I can move right now as I type this review and am unable to do so because I have no locomotives to pull the cars.
Advice to Management
I will start by prefacing that I have been identified by Sr. Management as a ‘high performer’ on the succession plan list. Despite this, I am looking for a new career. These are my thoughts: Jim Young (Former CEO and sadly deceased) often said that employees are the greatest resource of the Union Pacific Railroad. He made employees feel valued. He wasn’t perfect, however he was making strides in a company that is very ancient in its practices and policies. When Lance took over in 2015, nearly every action he took removed Jim’s hard work. We have since had layoffs in 2015, 2017, 2018, and 2019. In addition, countless employees have taken early retirements or resigned to find a better career. I alone in my 5-10 years with the company have known 100 people that left, many of whom were high performers. The company can always buy new track, locomotives or other fixed assets. We will never gain back the talent we have lost. I went from loving the company to now searching for a new career. When I walk through headquarters, I look around and hardly recognize the place I work for. Every employee is in survival mode and is working in fear to protect their job. Below are some of my recommendations however I think Sr. Management likes things just the way they are. 
My recommendation to Sr. Mgmt: Be open and honest about what you are trying to do. Quit with the UP Pride b/s. Your employees see right through it. It’s pretty much propaganda, no better than North Korean media. If you don’t care about us and expect us to work our butts off purely for a paycheck than say that. At first I didn’t like Vena but now I respect his transparency. He at least tells us to expect more workforce reductions. If this isn’t the environment you want, then you will need to oust Lance and bring back a leader people can rally to. Also, give us the resources we need. I am figgin tired of not having enough locomotives to run my trains and when I call the shop they say they don’t have enough personnel to fix the broken units. Anyway... I have trains to move. I’m going to start ranting and I don’t have all day and night to write this review.
Helpful (12

Hours - 3 shifts run 24 hrs a day. Takes a decade to be able to work 6-2 pm. 7 days a week so expect tues /wed off as a New hire and for your first 10 yrs.
Advice to Management
Before its too late, get back to what made UP GREAT - ITS PEOPLE. We are SHOCKED to see the number of employees quitting because they know they are just a number. We are told things like... "we are good for this month, no layoffs " - it really gives you that temporary employee feel. Adults with families work hard for companies that commit to security of employment. 

Without a degree your chances of any promotions are literally nil. Foreman spots are going away, even manager positions are in danger. Negotiated raises don't keep up with inflation as other benefits are cut or costs raised. 
Local managements hands are tied by corporate office.

review_title: Good Pay, Easy Job, Huge Responsibility
pros: Excellent pay and great benefits. It's a fun job if you don't let the pessimists get to you. UP will be around for a long time. Just find a position that technology won't take sometime in the near future.
cons:
Expect to work shifts/jobs that you don't enjoy for the first 2 -5 years or more, depending on seniority. Many layoffs and cutting other essential resources in order to save money. Expect to pay dues to a Union every month that honestly doesn't do as much as we would all hope. Technology is growing exponentially on the tracks and my educated guess is that it won't be long until UP moves from 2 man crews-->1 man crews-->Trains operating themselves. Unfortunately, when it comes to managers and crews, there isn't much collaboration but rather confrontation and resistance. Front-line managers are usually great to work with but their superiors put a lot of pressure on them to make the impossible happen which is likely due to not really being exposed to the fine details of the actual operation.
Advice to Management
UP absolutely needs to give their employees some INCENTIVE if they want them to perform at the levels they are capable of. These men and women on the ground are smart and creative and will really surprise you when they're at their most productive. The problem is that there is no INCENTIVE to 1.) get there faster 2.)switch more cars 3.) go above and beyond 4.) be flexible and perform other duties. When all of us first interviewed for a job, we promised that we would work hard and do our best, but years of distrust and seeing others get fired for breaking a rule (there are a lot of rules, there's one for everything you do on the property), most of us would rather play it safe than help out the RR. It wouldn't take much to apply some INCENTIVE to the employees. Bonuses for high productivity, bringing "quits" back, recognition for consistently showing up to work, paying higher trip rates for thru-freight instead of promising overtime after 8 hours, giving the crews more independence when it comes to making decisions, and certainly stopping the incentive's for managers to find the most minor FTX "failures" on their crews; the list goes on... In today's railroad you don't get paid more for being a better employee, you don't get to go home early after your work is done, all you do is risk your job and your family's financial security. There is a saying that I hear often on the railroad, "The more you do.... the more you do."

Also, keep MYO's and S/MTO's in one location longer than a year or 2. It seems that once a manager really starts to get knowledgeable about the operation, they are shipped off to another state and replaced by someone who has to spend a lot of time building trust with the crews.
Helpful (4

advice_to_mgmt: Don't cut people off to save a million dollars when you make a few billion per quarter

pros: Looks good on a resume.
cons:
Where to begin? 

1. Zero work/life balance. If you are a manager in department that operates 24/7/365, you are expected to be on call 24/7/365. This means you are subject to being called in to cover someone else’s shift if they call in, with barely any notice. You are also “encouraged” to have your email set up on your personal phone so you don’t miss anything when you’re not in the office. You’re also bothered when on vacation and are never really “away”. Many times, I’d work 60-70+ hours each week and still had to be on-call regardless. 
2. Long hours. The ones in the “glass palace” work a modest 8-5 with a lunch break and have time to go to the on-site gym. The ones at the Harriman work a minimum of 10-hour days with no lunch (they can’t tell you that you CAN’T take a lunch, but it’s frowned upon to leave and get something to eat. Most just eat at their desks).
3. The HDC also does not have a gym on-site for employees to use. It’s a mile and a half from the UP HQ building, so it would be impossible to get a workout in over lunch. 
4. Incompetent management and nepotism runs rampant. People are promoted based upon their popularity rather than their skill level, tenure, and knowledge of the railroad. 
5. Management and directors will block people from interviewing for promotions because they’re worried about losing good employees. 
6. Management and directors will also hold employees for MONTHS until a replacement is hired. Oftentimes, the new department rescinds their offer because they can’t get the employee in time, leading to the employee not getting a promotion they rightfully earned. 
7. Unrealistic expectations set forth by management.
8. Attitude from subordinates that are never addressed by senior leadership, which leads to a negative work environment. Everyone is constantly walking on eggshells as to not say something that may get them subject to an EEO investigation. 
9. Participation in work-related groups and events is discouraged by managers, even though they want us to be involved in activities per our TPT/performance review. Lose/lose situation here.
10. CONSTANT layoffs. There have been a round of layoffs every single year I was here, with more coming. The executives don’t understand the bigger picture. All they care about is padding their wallets. In turn, these constant layoffs create added stress on the employees that were left, because they have to pick up the work that their peers used to do on top of their own.
Advice to Management
STOP WITH THE LAYOFFS. It is doing you NO good. You’re losing so many valuable employees that have given their blood, sweat, and tears to the company and that is how you repay them. You hired a new COO who was there to make sure PSR got off the ground, paying him MILLIONS in the process, while laying off hundreds of employees. Save yourselves the money and cut back on all these executives’ and board members’ salaries and keep the employees you need.

pros: Pay, Satisfying Work, Met some good people
cons:
I've been putting off my review because I didn't know where to begin. It's been over a year since I left and I still get upset when I think deeply about my time with UP.

Well first off I have to say the culture was terrible. Nobody seemed to care about anything, much less completing the minimum assigned tasks. When work was performed it would be only what was explicitly assigned. Nobody owned their work or took pride in what they did.

The unions and management have a terrible relationship. I often felt like I was caught in between 2 divorced parents when dealing with the two, and in the end I resented both of them for it.

When I would insist on doing my job correctly and tried to favor long term solutions over short term fixes management would likely be upset, or indifferent at a minimum. For example: One of my coworkers at my current job quit working at UP after only a few weeks after getting into an argument with a foreman where the foreman was upset the he had done his job correctly and in accordance with federal, and company standards.

For a time I helped install PTC equipment on locomotives. This was a task the company grudgingly completed and it showed. After failing to meet deadline after deadline the company would complain to congress about how difficult it was and how hard they were trying. This got them yet another extension. The company then turned around and laid-off over 50% of the installers. 

My problem wasn't with the work. I actually enjoyed what I did, but every day felt like an ethical compromise. 

The company simply doesn't care about job performance or customer satisfaction. Shortly after they rolled out their arrogant G55+0 plans a few of us began crafting our own GTFO90+0 plans and made sure we weren't stuck on the last chopper out of Saigon. I have no regrets.
Helpful (10

cons:
Profits are all that matter. Period
Advice to Management
Take control back from board members
Helpful (4
advice_to_mgmt: Take control back from board members

pros: There are no longer any "pro" reasons for working at Union Pacific. And I highly doubt there will be any "pro" reason for working at Union Pacific in the future.
cons:
Union Pacific has floundered under current 'leadership'. They can no longer sustain a positive workforce due to unending cuts to workforce, budgets, and benefits. My role was underappreciated and underpaid (salary / bonus / raise). I lacked the tools I continuously requested as a requirement to do my job effectively due to 'budget'. I know for a fact that many people in my previous department received bonuses and retention stock DOUBLE my annual salary, yet I was unable to get training or new supplies to complete my daily tasks. And my raises and bonuses were a slap in the face. Certain people snagged interviews for jobs they might not even be qualified for as "favors"...sometimes those individuals received those promotions. It's all who you know, who you're related to, and who 'owes you one'... If you speak up regarding ANYTHING shady or suspect, your claims / issues are buried and forgotten. The offenders are protected and shielded from any repercussions and you will be told that their supervisor will handle redirect privately and internally. This never ends up happening. The employee engagement surveys continue to come back worse and worse. They have made little to no change regarding this feedback. They are moving backwards. Even their steps forwards (paid parental leave for fathers) is pathetic and antiquated. Other companies are beginning to offer unlimited vacation packages, paid parking downtown, significant paid family leave packages that include maternity leave for mothers and fathers...Union Pacific is failing. And with each cut to their workforce, they are committing to more and more failure. I fear for those on the ground operating the trains and doing the real work. Someone is going to be pushed too far, too hard for too long and end up injured or worse...
Advice to Management
Management has refused to listen to warnings for several years now...many people who's voices were silenced have since left the company (myself being one of them)... I'm writing this review for those who are left and those who are looking at joining Union Pacific. Please do yourself a service and find employment elsewhere. I heard straight from Lance's lips that "every company is like this ... this happens at other companies and it's business." It's not. He's lying. He's abused this company for long enough. Please believe that nearly anywhere is better than Union Pacific.

pros: This used to be an exceptional job. Railroad jobs in general are trending down. Wages are down and healthcare costs have shot up. Expected to work 2nd or third shift with no added compensation. Will need 20+ years before you can be on first shift with either a Saturday or Sunday off. Want them both off on first shift? You’ll have to wait 25 years. Current management philosophy is screw the workers and give everything to stockholders. UP got 6 billion in taxes back, made 1.6 billion in the third quarter alone ( a new record), stock returns were up 43% and they laid off workers that they offered hiring bonuses to a year ago. If you can stomach working outdoors 70-80% of the time, not see your family and don’t mind shift work, railroad retirement is pretty good.

review_title: May you live in interesting times
pros: The retirement plan, at the time I was hired (it's changed since), was very good, and a major selling point for retention and hiring of employees. Also, there's a great training program for new IT workers, and an energized culture for improving and augmenting the railroad's tech stack.
cons:
- Like a lot of other Fortune 500 firms, UP currently has a single-minded dedication to ticking off all the cynical late-stage capitalism stereotypes they can. Layoffs, pay cuts, benefit cuts in the face of record profits and corporate tax cuts, all for the sake of improving the all-holy operating ratio number.
- The "Unified Plan 2020" that was recently announced will make things very, very interesting over the next few years.
- Going along with the above two, the retirement plan is pretty useless if hanging around for a long career is increasingly rare.
- Location in Omaha, NE has hurt recruitment and leads to a glut of new employees from the same universities. The culture of suburban Nebraska has caused problems for minority and LGBT employees (though, to their credit, UP does seem to do as much as they can to mitigate this)
- Some teams in IT struggle with integrating all developers/workers into the team in a meaningful manner. This goes quadruple for high-priority projects; UP does not have the people capable of managing and architecting these projects, generally won't go out and find them, and won't listen to them when they do get them. Cold, antiseptic atmosphere leads to clannish, unfriendly teams.
Advice to Management
Ditch G55 and make meaningful future plans. Stop supporting politicians that enact trade policies that do long-term damage to your business.
Helpful (17
advice_to_mgmt: Ditch G55 and make meaningful future plans. Stop supporting politicians that enact trade policies that do long-term damage to your business.

pros: Invest a lot of time training you. My initial and final classroom trainer were fantastic. Middle conductor was terrible and constantly looking for an EEO violator. Not hard work at all. Check will always be good. Some of the "old heads" you worked with were pretty good, but it almost seemed like the younger ones were worse to work with. It is pretty cool having 9000hp at your fingertips.
cons:
Management constantly looking for rules violations and loved to make students an example for the most frivolous stuff. I was written up for walking through a mud puddle and crossing the track incorrectly. I never even crossed the track. Another manager accused my foreman of me of not crossing track correctly even after he said he was to far away to really see us. Coworkers are interested in one thing, getting an early quit, meaning working 7 hours. If you are new and slower, which it to be expected, and you mess up their early quit you will catch holy hell. They will tell you different, but most do not mean it. Once past training, you never know when you are going to work and only get 1.5 hours notice to report. Limits where you can go and what you can do. Married to your cell phone and it better get 100% coverage or you will get written up for that. Dispatch "lost" me and several other students in Cheyenne and had to spend multiple days without any pay even after calling dispatch center. pros:
- Given the cons, none really. When the company is so screwed up, flexible hours and a company gym don't really matter.

- They pay you a lot, but then fire you. I'd rather be paid less and keep my job.
cons:
- Mass layoffs in 2018 following mass layoffs in 2016 and others before that, including a layoff in 2002.

- Miniscule to non-existent design group, whether in track, signal, or structural design. As an idea, only about 6 engineers handle all the track and terminal design for a 32,000 mile track network. They can barely shuffle the paperwork to get the consultants paid...which is all they have time to do.

- CEO and COO are heartless, ignorant, and short-sighted copy cats of Hunter Harrison. Operating ratio is only metric they care about, and even though it is already in the 60s...which is already unsustainable and unrealistic...they have gutted what was left of the actual engineers that the company employs to lower it.

- Essentially no real engineering at UP, stay away if you are a PE who wants to combine field work and design experience. All they want are engineers to join their OMT program out of college and manage unionized workers. This makes no sense, because these folks are out of college and add little value to the field compared to an ex-union manager...nor do they have any jobs left in the office to develop their hard engineering skills and plow those skills back into the field.

- If you weren't good at engineering or don't particularly like it, and want to do long hours of managing workers and projects, with a consultant providing all the actual engineering, join UP. You won't have a life, you'll hardly have vacations, you won't learn much engineering, and some day, UP will fire you when the Operating Ratio is too high.

- Again, remember, they are firing people after several previous waves of layoffs, and gutted what was an already bare bones organization in a time of traffic congestion and service issues. How much worse can it get?
Advice to Management
- UPRR should be sued by the federal government and not allowed to paint an American flag, or use the slogan "Building America". The CEO and COO are the incarnation of 21st century American corporate greed and stupidity. Oh, and UPRR is incorporated in Delaware...they ask employees for local donations while paying taxes to a state in which they have no train tracks so they can make more money.

- C-suite, you have golden parachutes and are multi-millionaires, so you could destroy an American icon and it really makes no difference to your lives. Plus you won't read this, and even if you do, you'll disagree. My only purpose here is to alert your share holders that you put above your employees and customers...and of course, the American public, who gave you the land that you built your tracks on 150 years ago comes dead last. After all, you fired all the men and women who served as the field liaisons between the railroad and local governments in this last employee demolition derby.

- Operating ratio does not take into account capital costs. Railroads are one of the most, if not the most capital intensive business out there. Employees were fired to lower the OR, which will balloon capital costs as more work is contracted out. Service issues will go from a problem to a disaster since you gutted what was left of the intellectual leadership in Omaha. Don't invest in UP or the company it copied, CSX.

review_title: Antiquated perception, doesn't comprehend Midwest vs Silicon Valley
pros: I work at UPC (the headquarters) in Omaha, and the work environment here is truly wonderful. I'm in a group that has a feel like a genuine family, although I've been told that it is, by a VAST margin, the minority (possibly literally the only). There also is an incredible plethora of career paths a person can transition to.
cons:
We are underpaid, and undervalued. I realize everyone says that...however, I have one friend who was poached by another company who provides the exact same IT development services *TO THE RAILROAD* that this guy was already working on...and immediately went from $75k to $110k with guaranteed 10% bonus, minimum. I know multiple others who have been in the company for 20+ years who have been offered ~50% increase in salary elsewhere...they didn't take it only because they are in my same group that has a wonderful family feel (so do you want do be treated like a human being? or do you want to be paid properly? that seems to be the question.) This company, at least those in upper management, do(es) not comprehend the value of IT, programmed intelligence, or literally anything other than physical man-power on the ground and *management*. It disgusts me, because the few middle managers who brought me to the company, because of their brilliance, vision, and kindness, are the painful minority and don't actually represent the current state of upper management.
Advice to Management
Please realize that Omaha is in the middle of the Midwest, and that is *NOT*, I repeat *NOT* a positive fact. For those who grew up here, it may be. That is the vast minority. HR compares salaries to other equivalent companies, and scales them based on cost of living....not quality of life.

pros:
Decent pay. Great insurance and 401k match
The opportunity to become a manager right out of college is rare and unheard of for most companies. In the OMT program you are given the opportunity to learn from many different craft and managers to gain new skills. This a fantastic chance to start a career but after going through the program some things should be noted to all who are seeking this position.
cons:
When the position says you will be working 24/7/365 days a year it literally translates to holidays don’t exist and trying to get vacation for these days might not be possible because only so many managers can be off at a time. In mechanical you may work an 8-10 hour day but it usually means working 12-13 hours if you are covering for somebody else because they are on vacation which is very frequent at this time. The current schedule is a 5/2 or an 11/3. Yes, this could mean 11 days in a row working over 12 hours a day. Transportation works this frequently. Transportation usually runs a 12-13 hour a day. Many more hours than other companies. 
Vacation is now 3 weeks for starting out (similar to many companies now) but with no holidays unless they randomly fall on your rest days you are pretty much missing 11 paid days off. Almost two weeks short of what other companies are paying. Being non-agreement means that when you work on a holiday you won’t be paid more and if fact you are most likely to work even longer on a holiday to make up for the other manager who requested the time off. 
In most companies where you have to work shift work you get paid more for weekends, nights, or holidays but you will find no fairness here. In fact currently, facilities are running schedules that all managers don’t get a full weekend. For example, if you work 1st shift you may have two weekdays for your off days. If you work 2nd shift your off days could be Friday and Saturday. Some locations have a 6-month rotation. Some don’t mind this schedule but if you are religious or desire to do things on the weekend you won’t be able to possibly attend these activities for 6 months. 
Sick days only pertain to you so if your spouse is in the hospital plan on taking vacation time or unpaid time off. 
Heavy regulation on rules so much that the workers fear of even doing work. FTX program (coaching people on rules) has great intentions but has caused a great disgruntlement in the company. The company has made policy changes and working situations which overall makes unhappy workers which makes it hard to manage people.
Advice to Management
Overall, Union Pacific is a great company but has the opportunity to make some changes which I believe would change the outlook on the company. I believe that a person that just complains but doesn’t give solutions is not worth listening to so here would be my advice for the company. 
Time with family is the most crucial key element of the happiness of a worker. UP must stay open 24/7/365 a year but if managers are required to work Thanksgiving they can have Christmas off. Doing a holiday pod similar to the medical field or emergency response teams would be ideal. Setting up schedules that allow people to work the nights, weekends, and holidays and be paid more will allow other people who rather have that time off to be with family or in many cases one parent is allowed to work nights while the other works days. UP needs a company to come in and fix the work-life balance or they will find managers leaving faster than they can hire.
Helpful (12
advice_to_mgmt:
Overall, Union Pacific is a great company but has the opportunity to make some changes which I believe would change the outlook on the company. I believe that a person that just complains but doesn’t give solutions is not worth listening to so here would be my advice for the company. 
Time with family is the most crucial key element of the happiness of a worker. UP must stay open 24/7/365 a year but if managers are required to work Thanksgiving they can have Christmas off. Doing a holiday pod similar to the medical field or emergency response teams would be ideal. Setting up schedules that allow people to work the nights, weekends, and holidays and be paid more will allow other people who rather have that time off to be with family or in many cases one parent is allowed to work nights while the other works days. UP needs a company to come in and fix the work-life balance or they will find managers leaving faster than they can hire.

review_title: Interesting to say the least. Definitely not bad though.
pros: Allows you to think critically about issues you are facing and gives you the tools to figure out solutions. There are enormous opportunities to grow within the company and your career path is pretty much entirely up to you.
cons:
A quality work-life balance requires....work. The jobs in the field are grueling. Be prepared to work long hours. Biggest advice to employees is don't take your work home with you. Be present with your family. There are times when you have to answer that call at home, but do your best to be present with those who matter.
Advice to Management
Hire more employees. The biggest reason turnover is so high with employees (especially field managers) is that their workload and responsibilities are enormous. Just because one person can do a job, doesn't mean that is the most cost effective way to go about it. If you split that job between two people, you get a more thorough effort since the burden is shared, as opposed to one person completing it as fast as they can merely to get it off their plate for the next inevitable issue they will face.
 
By sharing the responsibilities among more people, you allow employees time to hone their skills and keep their minds working effectively, rather than exhaustedly. 

A good area to run an experiment is to find where the most people quit, and add EXTRA people to it. From there, you can watch their productivity and compare the historical data to your new data and measure how the employees respond to the change in categories that range from things like their personal wellbeing, to the terminals key measures. 

If all you do is keep re-filling positions as employees quit, there is really no change being made at all. To expect different results in the long run is irrational. "Insanity is doing the same thing over and over and expecting different results."

I know the efforts are in the process through the organizational restructuring, but the sooner the better.

review_title: This company is a joke to work for now.
pros: The ONLY pro is a steady paycheck, even though the pay is not competitive anymore. Did I say it’s a joke to work for now?
cons:
Work rules are stacked against you and you’re pretty much set up to get fired every day you clock in. They’ve taken it a step further by using drones to spy on you when you’re working out in the yards. 

Like doing a good job, and have pride in your work? Good, management will take advantage of that, and run you in to the ground. Find a problem outlined by the companies written standard work that could cause a locomotive to fail pulling a train? Dearly noted, but if your manager is one of the few that’s still employed that has worked their way up, they’re probably gonna tell you “I used to be a (mechanic/electrician) I’m sure that’s not gonna be a problem.” The kids fresh out of college that have a degree in religion, and can’t hold a wrench right will just ask “will it make a trip?”

Like doing the bare minimum, playing stupid, have no ambition to learn your job? This is a great place for you, because the few that are decent will be forced to pick up your slack, so go ahead, burn up that battery on your cell phone, management will run your union brothers in to the ground to pick up your slack. 

The pay is considerably less then the national average now, specially after this last contract that was a underhanded deal to “pass”. 

Safety is only relevant if it doesn’t hold up production. (That’s thanks to the shareholder driven CEO that’s out of touch with the boots on the ground people.) But get caught slipping up when there isn’t a crunch for that particular locomotive you’re working on, then they’re trying to fire you.

There’s no initiative to go above and beyond as well as work safe. Shareholders and operating ratios are more important then making employees feel valued/appreciated.

No weekends off, forced to work holidays, and you can expect be on second or third shift for the first few years.
Advice to Management
STOP TREATING YOUR EMPLOYEES LIKE TRASH!!! There’s a reason why the company has to offer 15 and 20k sign on bonuses to get people to come to work for them. The word is finally getting out that this is a garbage company to work for, and I’m glad. I’ve seen this company royally screw good employees over, and ruin lifes. And for the hoops you have to jump through aren’t worth it for the salary paid. Yes the company comeback to that would be “well your unions negotiate your wages, blah blah blah...” BUT we get to see what our unions propose. The company just says nope. Even after 10 years of record profits, and the trump tax breaks. 

I have 13 years in, and just like many 8+ year employees we’ve seen the steady decline. Moral is the worst I’ve seen, as well as it’s just flat out hostel. I used to love what I do for a living, and was proud to work for UP. Now I clock in, and I’m just like “screw this, fire me”. But I’m good at what I do, and they need me so I’m not that lucky I guess. (Reread second paragraph in cons) 

Bring back employee perks/incentives. Hats and coffee mugs are a slap in the face when all we’ve heard for the last 10 years is “RECORD PROFITS!!!” We show up to work for MONEY not coffee mugs. Bring back safety days!!!! Maybe give some stock, or profit sharing. But whatever, make sure it’s MEANINGFUL. A $25 Walmart gift card is also a slap in the face. (Again record profits) heck, $25 barely covers a case of beer that I need after work to cope with my day after I clock out.

Unfortunately, it’s gonna be too little too late.

review_title: High Manager Turn Over, Strained Relationships with Workers, New ideas not welcome.
pros:
Insurance is better for Union than it is for management, but management is still decent. 
Pay is alright, once you have a family though your hours are not worth it. 
Bonuses. We get more bonuses than any of the Union workers. 
Many other opportunities other than Operations Management... if you can get there.
cons:
Literal screaming and cursing from senior management.
Innovation is truly not welcomed by local leadership, corporate claims its wanted.
Company restructures often and silently. 
Stress. They say they have programs for it etc, but all of your bosses expect you to be on call, be there when they call, doesn’t matter if you are at a wedding, birthday party, doesn’t matter. You get called, you come or your fired. 
Want another opportunity or promotion? Prepare to move. Also if local leadership literally needs you to stay, you’ll never leave. They can make phone calls to their friends in other areas and will tell them not to take you, that you are too valuable to them in your current position. I have seen this happen to two of my colleagues. 
“Us vs Them” mentality by senior management when it comes to how we can interact with Union. We are forced to write up “failures” in Field Training Exercises that goes on the workers records. The workers are smart though and know that rules contradict themselves, and worse are left up to the manager doing the observations to say if they looked long enough before crossing tracks, or threw switches correctly. If we do not have enough “failures” we get an inordinate amount of pressure from local leadership as their bonuses are affected by it. 
99.9 percent of railroad property is located in dangerous, impoverished areas of cities. We do not have enough police officers for the Union guys, and we are regularly called to investigate trespassing, accidents etc with little protection.
Self insured company, one catastrophic incident totally outside of your control, anywhere in the system and we are out of business… the company lets you know this. One incident, and no matter how much of your life has been dedicated to the organization, its gone. 
If you want experience in management for your resume, do as 70% of my peers do, leave once you have the minimum time your next position requires. Don’t believe me? Don’t worry, they usually tell you about it at the introduction to management.
Advice to Management
My advice to board is clean up the top of this company. Senior leadership needs to immediately be replaced to stop the hemorrhaging of talented leaders and workers (which btw we have to hire whoever meets the minimum qualification because word is out how this organization is ran). 
Another word to the board, the only way this organization changes is if the press finds out about something we do, or there is a failure that causes loss of life, or injury. Then and only then do we address the issue… usually by creating a rule that does not address the true issues such as rushed employees even though we have to hammer in them that safety is key… we also hammer in them that our cost per car has to remain lower than it is otherwise everyone looses their jobs. Its hard to retain good employees because every 6 years or so we let them go as business slows…. Because we don’t care about the little industries and thus are at the mercy of national business, closely tied with the national economy/politics. 
I have too many years invested in this company to leave, but you have the chance to give our organization the edge by getting new leadership with fresh ideas about innovation and labor relations. It wears on all of my peers as we are constantly told to “find failures” and document them or else we are blackballed in phone calls by senior leadership, threatened politely via email. So many bad or ended marriages in management due to work hours, stress, constant calls while we are at home. Its not found in other organizations.
Helpful (13

pros: UP is a great starter job for a young electrician, or a stable career for someone who wants to settle down into mediocrity. Once you figure out your job, it can be very easy/boring (however you want to see it) and not very challenging (beware your skills as an electrician can diminish greatly!). The pay is decent considering the amount of actual work you do vs. downtime (there is a lot of downtime!). Can be a nice addition to a resume for future work. Again, great for a young employee to help get started, but not so great for long term.
cons:
UP has unfortunately cut down on a lot of jobs, so chances of advancement are very little, and if you do advance, it might not be worth it. The benefits are decent, but comparable to other union jobs in the industry so nothing to brag about there, but I will mention we get NO SICK DAYS! For a company who puts great emphasis on safety, they really give you no choice but to come to work feeling ill and putting you and others at risk. Not unless you are willing to lose money. Expect to work 2nd or 3rd shift and on weekends, and expect to NEVER see a Mon-Fri job on 1st shift (or any shift for that matter). The company seems to love to bring morale down, and it definitely shows. I swear almost every employee is a disgruntled employee! The culture certainly has been changing recently, and not for the better.
Advice to Management
You have to understand that morale plays a great role in production and safety in a workplace, and sometimes that needs to be addressed, too. Hire and promote from within the company. You have a lot of talented people eager to grow, but you decide to hire someone straight out of college with no real management or locomotive experience. Also instead of cutting jobs that are in place to improve productivity to save money, figure out how to save money by cutting waste by actually improving productivity.

pros: Pros are diminishing every year. Pay and Benefits used to be great, but not true any more.
cons:
Senior Leadership. Cuts, cuts, cuts. Command by fear used to be the only real issue, now leadership has added demoralization by title reduction and workload increase through staff cuts. The departments that do the least work came out on top while Operations continues to take the brunt of the abuse. Morale is so low and the workloads so immense, that service has declined severely and continues to do so.
MRV's are dropping $5,000 - $50,000 due to the title changes. The thankless jobs used to be well compensated, but the current structure is driving the best people away from those jobs and into positions that have better hours of service and time off.
Advice to Management
Clean house. Replace Senior Leadership with only leaders that have worked their way up from within the company. It's obvious our current CEO does not know which departments drive the rise and fall of service and therefore the company as a whole. He does not understand transportation, nor customer service.
Reset title levels to what they were. MRV's are going to drive away the best of us if not fixed soon. Stop acting like Sales is the most important department. Selling a great product and great service is easy. Our current service is about to make those folks finally earn some of their over-inflated salaries.
Remember, you may be able to CUT to 55 and drive up the stock price, but service will continue to suffer as it has. Stock results cannot be sustained if customer satisfaction and rail service continue to deteriorate. 
When the STB is sending class 1's letters about poor service, wake up and realize you've made a big mistake that needs to be rectified asap.
